title: 106_s382
content: The Act may be cited as the "Minuteman Missile National Historic Site Establishment Act of 1999". Congress finds that the Minuteman II intercontinental ballistic missile launch control facility and launch facility known as "Delta 1" and "Delta 9" are significant examples of American history during the Cold War. These facilities symbolize the dedication of Air Force missileers stationed in remote locations, provide insight into the Cold War, arms race, and ICBM development, and fill a gap in the National Park System's representation of the Cold War. The Act aims to preserve and interpret structures related to the Minuteman II missile defense system, highlight its historical significance in America's strategic commitment to world peace and the Cold War, and enhance interpretive programs offered by the South Dakota Air and Space Museum. The Act establishes the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site to preserve structures related to the Minuteman II missile defense system. The Minuteman Missile National Historic Site is established in South Dakota as part of the National Park System. It includes the Minuteman II ICBM launch control facilities, specifically the Delta 1 and Delta 9 Launch Facilities. A map of the site is available for public inspection. The Secretary of the Interior can make minor adjustments to the boundary of the Minuteman Missile National Historic Site. The site will be administered in accordance with relevant laws applicable to the National Park System. The Secretary may consult with other agencies, enter cooperative agreements, and acquire land for the historic site within specified methods, excluding contaminated land. The Secretary may not acquire contaminated land under this Act unless all necessary remedial actions have been taken. Land in South Dakota can only be acquired by donation or exchange. Within 3 years of funds availability, a general management plan for the historic site must be prepared by the Secretary. The Secretary must prepare a general management plan for the historic site, including evaluating locations for a visitor facility and administrative site. Once the appropriate location is determined, the site boundary will be modified to include the selected site. Coordination with Badlands National Park is required in developing the plan. The Secretary is tasked with preparing a general management plan for the historic site, which includes consolidating administrative, management, and personnel functions with Badlands National Park. SEC. 4 of the Act authorizes appropriations for carrying out the provisions. The Secretary of the Air Force is required to transfer funds specifically appropriated for land maintenance to establish and maintain the historic site. The Legacy Resource Management Program funds for resource preservation and treaty compliance are not affected by this Act.
